description.short: A UNESCO World Heritage site known for its glacier-capped mountains.
description.long: Rwenzori Mountains National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage site, home to the famous 'Mountains of the Moon.' With glaciers, snow-capped peaks, waterfalls, and diverse flora and fauna, the park is a top destination for trekking and nature lovers.

description.short: Uganda’s vibrant capital city, full of history and culture.
description.long: Kampala, the capital of Uganda, is a bustling city known for its markets, historical landmarks, cultural sites like the Kasubi Tombs, and the Ugandan Museum. It offers a blend of modernity with deep-rooted traditions, making it a unique city to explore.

image.alt: A view of Kampala city center
image.license: Jepsen, Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported

description.short: Home to the powerful Murchison Falls and abundant wildlife.
description.long: Murchison Falls National Park is Uganda’s largest national park, known for its dramatic waterfalls where the Nile River plunges 43 meters. The park is also famous for its wildlife safaris, offering a chance to see elephants, lions, giraffes, and hippos.

image.alt: Murchison Falls in Murchison Falls National Park

description.short: A UNESCO World Heritage site and home to mountain gorillas.
description.long: Bwindi Impenetrable National Park is famous for its population of mountain gorillas. A UNESCO World Heritage site, the park is covered in dense rainforests and offers one of the best gorilla trekking experiences in the world, along with rich biodiversity.

image.alt: Mountain gorillas in Bwindi Impenetrable National Park
image.license: Creative Commons Zero, Public Domain Dedication

description.short: A popular safari destination with diverse wildlife and landscapes.
description.long: Queen Elizabeth National Park is Uganda’s most visited national park, offering incredible wildlife safaris. The park is home to lions, elephants, hippos, and the famous tree-climbing lions of Ishasha. Its varied landscapes include savannahs, wetlands, and lakes.

image.alt: Elephants in Queen Elizabeth National Park
image.license: Creative Commons Zero, Public Domain Dedication

description.short: The largest lake in Africa and a key ecological and cultural landmark.
description.long: Lake Victoria is the largest lake in Africa and the second largest freshwater lake in the world. It spans multiple countries and is vital to the communities around it. The Ugandan side of the lake offers boating, fishing, birdwatching, and access to islands like Ssese.

description.short: A remote and stunning wilderness park in northeastern Uganda.
description.long: Kidepo Valley National Park is one of Uganda’s most isolated and beautiful parks. It offers rugged landscapes, sweeping valleys, and rich wildlife, including lions, elephants, zebras, and cheetahs. Its remote location makes it one of the less visited parks, offering an off-the-beaten-path experience.

image.alt: Buffalos in Kidepo Vally National Park
image.license: Creative Commons Zero, Public Domain Dedication

description.short: A sanctuary dedicated to the conservation of Uganda’s rhinos.
description.long: Ziwa Rhino Sanctuary is Uganda’s only place where you can see rhinos in the wild. The sanctuary is committed to rhino conservation and reintroducing rhinos into Uganda's parks. It offers guided rhino tracking and other wildlife viewing opportunities.

image.license: Bernard DUPONT (https://www.flickr.com/people/65695019@N07), Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.0

description.short: A scenic archipelago in Lake Victoria known for relaxation and adventure.
description.long: The Ssese Islands are an archipelago of 84 islands located in the northwestern part of Lake Victoria. Popular for their serene beaches, lush forests, and abundant birdlife, the islands offer a peaceful escape with options for fishing, boating, and hiking.

image.license: Saidi Hussen, Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0

description.short: The point where the Nile River begins its journey from Lake Victoria.
description.long: The Source of the Nile is located in Jinja, Uganda, where the Nile River starts its long journey towards Egypt. The site is popular for boat rides and offers stunning views of the Nile’s beginning, as well as opportunities for adventure activities like white-water rafting.
